subject: p11052935
History: -year-old male with shortness of breath and cough. Question pneumonia.
Findings: Frontal and lateral views of the chest demonstrate normal cardiomediastinal silhouette. The lungs appear hyperexpanded, in keeping with known emphysema. Previously seen left lower lobe opacity has resolved on the frontal view but may persist on lateral view obscuring the posterior costophrenic angle, which could represent a component of residual infection and/or atelectasis. There is trace basilar atelectasis on the right. There is no large effusion. Eventration is seen on the right, unchanged.
Impression: Bibasilar dependent atelectasis. Persistent probable left lower lobe posterior opacity which could represent atelectasis or a component of residual infection, to be clinically correlated. Followup after treatment recommending to document resolution.
